overview: This unit covers the foundational concepts related to sensation and perception, focusing on the evolution of minds and bodies, basic neural functions, and the structure of cognition as it relates to behavior.

key_points: Brains reflect evolution and are not designed like computers.
Solutions in biological systems build upon and subsume existing solutions.
Evolutionary constraints and historical reuse influence brain structure and function.
sections.narrative: Minds and bodies have evolved over time, which is different from computers that are designed. Brains reflect evolution, meaning that solutions are built upon and subsume previous solutions. This leads to incremental changes and constrains brain structure and function.

key_points: Foundational functions include avoiding negative stimuli and approaching positive stimuli.
Basic behaviors involve turning toward or away from stimuli.

sections.narrative: The foundational functions of the brain include avoiding negative stimuli and approaching positive stimuli. These behaviors involve turning toward or away from a stimulus. Complex behavior arises from the elaboration of these basic functions, improving control of behavior. These basic behaviors can be observed even in simple organisms.

overview: This unit delves into the process of transforming electromagnetic radiation into visual information, focusing on the early visual pathway, the role of the retina and its components, and the properties of retinal ganglion cells.

key_points: The early visual pathway involves the cornea, pupil, lens, retina, and optic nerve.
The retina encodes the location and wavelength of light.
Cones are more prevalent in the fovea and are sensitive to specific wavelengths (color).
Rods are more numerous in the periphery and are more sensitive to light intensity.
sections.narrative: The early visual pathway begins with light entering the eye through the cornea and pupil. The lens focuses the light onto the retina, where specialized cells encode the location and wavelength of light. Cones, located mainly in the fovea, are responsible for color vision and require more light. Rods, located in the periphery, are more sensitive to light intensity and are used for night vision.

key_points: Retinal ganglion cells are of two types: Magnocellular (M) and Parvocellular (P).
Magnocellular cells mainly receive input from rods, have many inputs, and are light and motion sensitive.
Parvocellular cells mainly receive input from cones, have few inputs, and preserve detail and color.
sections.narrative: Retinal ganglion cells are classified into two main types: Magnocellular (M) and Parvocellular (P) cells. Magnocellular cells receive input mainly from rods, have many inputs, and are fast and sensitive to light and motion. Parvocellular cells receive input mainly from cones, have fewer inputs, and are slower but preserve detail and color information.
